chapter.para: This chapter details the various procedures you can use to build a new &productname; &productnumber; cluster.
There are two ways to build a cluster, one of which has two variants.

listitem.para: Installing nodes from installation media (for virtual machines, directly from ISO images, or physical media for bare-metal installations).

warning.title: &Admin_Node;
warning.para: You must install the &admin_node; first and configure it using &dashboard; before installing the other nodes in the cluster.

listitem.para: With this method, there are two ways to install the worker nodes:
Individually, choosing the node type during installation. This is only feasible for a small number of workers.

Installing the worker nodes using &ay; so that they receive their configuration automatically from the &admin_node;. This is the recommended method for larger clusters, but it is equally suitable for small clusters.
With both methods, the procedure to install the &admin_node; is identical. Only installation process for the &worker_node;s differs.

note.para: It is possible to start setup using PXE. For the full procedure, refer to the &sle; 12 Deployment Guide: .

You can directly use the initrd and linux files from your install media, or install the package tftpboot-installation-CAASP-3.0 onto your TFTP server. The package provides the required initrd and linux files in the /srv/tftpboot/ directory. You will need to modify the paths used in the &sle; 12 Deployment Guide to correctly point to the files provided by the package.

sect1.title: Installation from ISO images or media

sect2.title: Installing the &Admin_Node;
sect2.para: The procedure for installing the &admin_node; is identical whether or not you use &ay; for the rest of the cluster.

step.para: Connect or insert the &productname; installation media, then reboot the computer to start the installation program. On machines with a traditional BIOS, you will see the graphical boot screen shown below. The boot screen on machines equipped with UEFI is slightly different.
SecureBoot on UEFI machines is supported.

&kdump; saves the memory image (core dump) to the file system in case the kernel crashes. This enables you to find the cause of the crash by debugging the dump file. For more information, see .

warning.title: &kdump; with large amounts of RAM
warning.para: If you have a system with large amounts of RAM or a small hard drive, core dumps may not be able to fit on the disk. If the installer warns you about this, there are two options:

listitem.para: Enter the Expert Partitioner and increase the size of the root partition so that it can accommodate the size of the core dump. In this case, you will need to decrease the size of the data partition accordingly. Remember to keep all other parameters of the partitioning (e.g. the root file system, mount point of data partition) when doing these changes.

View detailed hardware information by clicking System Information. In this screen you can also change Kernel Settings. See

tip.title: Installing Product Patches at Installation Time
tip.para: If &productname; has been successfully registered at the &scc;, you are asked whether to install the latest available online updates during the installation. If you choose Yes, the system will be installed with the most current packages without having to apply the updates after installation. Activating this option is recommended.

step.para: After you have finalized the system configuration on the Installation Overview screen, click Install. Up to this point no changes have been made to your system.
Click Install a second time to start the installation process.
During the installation, the progress is shown in detail on the Details tab.
After the installation routine has finished, the computer will reboot into the installed system.

warning.title: Adjust overlay network to avoid collision with existing services
warning.para: The overlay network settings have to be verified and adjusted so that they do not collide with any services / addresses in the infrastructure that potentially need to be reached from any node or service running within the &productname; cluster.

For example, an oracle database is running on 172.16.4.5 in the existing infrastructure and a pod in the cluster needs to contact that database. Then, the defaults be adjusted to provide a different overlay network. Another example would be an NFS server or a SES/Ceph cluster running anywhere in the network 172.16.0.0/13 and where persistent storage access of the CaaSP cluster should be hosted on.

sect3.title: Automatic Installation Using &ay;
sect3.para: Before installing &worker_node;s with &ay;, you need to obtain the URL that points to the &ay; file on the &admin_node;. Generally, this will be supplied by the &dashboard; dashboard on the &admin_node;.

step.para: Insert the &productname; DVD into the drive, then reboot the computer to start the installation program.
Select Installation on the boot screen, but do not press .
Before proceeding to boot the machine, you should enter the necessary Boot Options for &ay; and networking.
The most important options are:

listitem.para: Path to the &ay; file. It is in the form of a URL built from the FQDN of the &admin_node;, followed the path to the &ay; file. For example, http://admin.example.com/autoyast
For more information, refer to .
Network configuration. If you are using dhcp, you can simply enter netsetup=dhcp. For manual configuration, refer to .
The host name for the node, if not provided by DHCP. If you manually specify a host name, make sure that it is unique.

step.para: Press . This boots the system and loads the &productname; installer.
So long as there are no errors, the rest of the installation should complete automatically. After a reboot, the new node should appear in the dashboard and can be added to your cluster.

note.title: &rootuser; Password
note.para: When nodes are installed using &ay;, there is no opportunity to specify the password for &rootuser;. However, each node will have ssh keys for &rootuser; on the &master_node; pre-installed. Thus it is possible to access the &worker_node;s by opening an ssh session from the &master_node;.

sect1.title: Using Pre-installed Disk Images
sect1.para: For building clusters from virtual machines on supported hypervisors, it is not necessary to individually install each node. &suse; offers pre-installed VM disk images in the following formats:

listitem.para: In QCOW2 format, for &kvm; and for &xen; using full virtualization.
In QCOW2 format, for &xen; using paravirtualization.
In VMDK format, for VMware ESXi.
For Microsoft Hyper-V.

sect2.title: Overview
sect2.para: When deploying a cluster node from pre-installed disk images, the setup program never runs. Thus, it is not possible to set values such as time servers, node names, the &rootuser; password for the &admin_node; and so on in the normal way.

Instead, you need to set these values using cloud-init configuration files. You should place these into a specific subdirectory, then make an ISO image. Attach this to the VM as a secondary disk. The pre-installed operating system on the disk image looks for a medium with the volume label cidata, searches that volume for the configuration files, and applies the settings within them.
Full details of the cloud-init metadata files can be found in the Configuration chapter of this manual; for more information, see .
As with individual node installation, the &admin_node; needs to be configured separately and differently from the &worker_node;s.

sect2.title: Installation on &soc;
sect2.para: You can deploy a &productname; on &soc; using &ostack;. You will need a &productname; machine image and &ostack; Heat templates. Once you have created a stack, you will continue with the &productname; setup.

note.title: &productname; machine image for &soc;
note.para: Download the latest &productname; for &ostack; image from https://download.suse.com (for example, SUSE-CaaS-Platform-3.0-OpenStack-Cloud.x86_64-1.0.0-GM.qcow2).

note.title: &ostack; Heat Templates Repository
note.para: &productname; Heat templates are available from GitHub.

step.para: Go to Project → Compute → Images and click on Create Image.
Give your image a name (for example: CaaSP-3); you will need to use this later to find the image.
Go to Project → Orchestration and click on Stacks.

Click on Launch Stack and provide the stack templates. Either upload the files, provide the URL to the raw files directly (only applies to stack template), or copy and paste the contents into the Direct Input fields.

warning.title: Replace the default root_password
warning.para: Do not use the caasp-environment.yaml directly from the GitHub repository.
You must make sure to replace the value for root_password with a secure password. This will become the password for the &rootuser; account on all nodes in the stack.

step.para: Click Next.
Now you need to define more information about the stack.

Select the machine flavor for your nodes

Select an external network that your cluster will be reachable from

Internal name server for the cluster

After the cluster has been started and the cluster overview shows Create Complete, you need to find the external IP address for the admin node of your cluster (here: 10.86.1.72). Now visit that IP address in your browser. You should see the &dashboard; login page and can continue with .

note.para:
You need to have access to the &ostack; command-line tools. You can either access those via ssh on your &soc; admin server or
install a local openstack client.
To use the local client, you need to access Project → Compute → Access & Security in the Horizon Dashboard and click on the Download &ostack; RC File v3.
The downloaded file is a script that you then need to load using the source command. The script will ask you for your &soc; password.

step.para: Upload the container image to &ostack; Glance (Image service). This example uses the name CaaSP-3 as the name of the image that is created in &soc;.

warning.title: Replace the default root_password
warning.para: Do not use the caasp-environment.yaml directly from the GitHub repository.
You must make sure to replace the value for root_password with a secure password. This will become the password for the &rootuser; account on all nodes in the stack.

step.para: Download the caasp-stack.yaml and caasp-environment.yaml Heat templates to your workstation and then run the openstack stack create command.
step.screen: &prompt.user;openstack stack create \ -t caasp-stack.yaml \ -e caasp-environment.yaml \ --parameter image=CaaSP-3 caasp3-stack

step.para: Find out which (external) IP address was assigned to the admin node of your &productname; cluster (here: 10.81.1.51).
Visit the external IP address in your browser. You should see the &dashboard; login page and can continue with .

sect2.title: Procedure for Hypervisors
sect2.para: The process is very similar for all hypervisors. The examples in this manual use &kvm; running on &sle;.

You need to build at least two ISO images with configuration information: one for the &admin_node; and one for the &worker_node;s. If you wish to assign specific host names or customize individual &worker_node;s, then you should create separate ISO images for each node.

Additionally, you need to make a separate copy of the downloaded VM disk image for each VM. We suggest keeping the original download elsewhere and making a fresh copy for each node, naming it appropriately: for example, caas-admin, caas-master, caas-worker1, caas-worker2 and so on.

sect3.title: Configuration Files
sect3.para: There are two separate configuration files: user-data and meta-data. Each node needs both. Thus, you need to prepare at a minimum one pair of files for the &admin_node;, and another pair of files for all the &worker_node;s.
Place the files into subdirectories named cc-admin for the &admin_node; and cc-worker for the &worker_node;s.
So, for instance, if your working directory is ~/cloud-config, then for the admin node, you need these two files:
The same meta-data file can be used for both node types. Here is an sample meta-data file:
sect3.screen: #cloud-config instance-id: iid-CAAS01 network-interfaces: | auto eth0 iface eth0 inet dhcp
sect3.para: The user-data file contains settings such as time servers, the &rootuser; password, and the node type.
Here is an example cc-admin/user-data file for an &admin_node;:
sect3.screen: #cloud-config debug: True disable_root: False ssh_deletekeys: False ssh_pwauth: True chpasswd: list: | root:MY_PASSWORD expire: False ntp: servers: - ntp1.example.com - ntp2.example.com runcmd: - /usr/bin/systemctl enable --now ntpd suse_caasp: role: admin
sect3.para: Here is an example cc-worker/user-data for a &worker_node;. Rather than providing the &rootuser; password in clear text, you can use a hash instead; this example is hashed with SHA-256.
sect3.screen: #cloud-config debug: True disable_root: False ssh_deletekeys: False ssh_pwauth: True chpasswd: list: | root:$5$eriogqzq$Dg7PxHsKGzziuEGkZgkLvacjuEFeljJ.rLf.hZqKQLA expire: False suse_caasp: role: cluster admin_node: caas-admin.example.com

sect3.title: Preparing an ISO image
sect3.para: Once you have edited the configuration files with your desired settings, you need to create an ISO image with the volume label cidata containing only the subdirectory for that node type.
On &sle; 12 or &opensuse; 42, use genisoimage to do this. On &sle; or &opensuse; 15, use mkisofs. The parameters are the same for both commands.
For example, to create the ISO image for an admin node on a computer running &opensuse; 42:

step.para: Make a folder called cc-admin.
In that folder, prepare user-data and meta-data files to set the &rootuser; password, node name and so on for the &admin_node;.
Create an ISO file called cc-admin.img containing these two files:
Create a new VM for the &admin_node;.
Attach a copy of the downloaded disk image as its main hard disk.
Attach the cc-admin.img disk image as a secondary disk.
Start the VM.
Configure the new &admin_node; as in step .

sect3.title: Procedure to Bring Up a &Worker_Node;
sect3.para: The first procedure is to generate the configuration files. Unless you wish to customize the individual &worker_node;s, then you need only do this part once.

step.para: Make a folder called cc-worker.

In that folder, prepare a user-data file to set the &rootuser; password, network settings and so on for the &worker_node;. If no changes are necessary, you can copy the meta-data file from that used to configure the &admin_node;.
Create an ISO file called cc-worker.img containing these two files:

sect3.para: Once you have a disk image containing the configuration files, it can be reused for multiple &worker_node;s.
Then, repeat the following steps for each &worker_node;:

step.para: Create a new VM for the &worker_node;.
Attach a copy of the downloaded disk image as its main hard disk.
Attach the cc-worker.img disk image as a secondary disk.
Start the VM.

sect3.para: Once you have brought up as many &worker_node;s as you need, proceed to bootstap the cluster using the &dashboard; dashboard.

sect1.title: Bootstrapping the Cluster

step.para:
Point a web browser to https://caasp-admin.&exampledomain;
to open the dashboard, where caasp-admin.&exampledomain; is the host name or IP address of the &admin_node;.
The dashboard lists all cluster nodes registered at the &admin_node;. Newly installed nodes are be listed as Pending Nodes. You can accept individual nodes or all by clicking Accept All Nodes.

Use the check box in the first column to select the nodes you want to add to your cluster. In the last column, select the one that should become &kube; master. All other nodes will be set to the worker role once you click Bootstrap cluster.
Please wait while the cluster is bootstrapped. Once finished, the status indicator icon of the nodes changes accordingly and you can download the kubectl config file kubeconfig.
